subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript
msgSnippet: ... Yes, I can make both changes. But I really would ask a concession from the rest of the group, and that is that we actually use English Sampa from now on.
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
>
>
> Thanks for all your effort, Paul. It looks great. Aside from the
> alternate letters, the only thing I noticed is that the name dot is
> still mapped to '/'. Personally I'd like to be able to type '/' in QS,
> which is one of the reasons I proposed moving the name dot to the
> backquote key. Also, are you planning to add angle brackets?

Yes, I can make both changes. But I really would ask a concession from
the rest of the group, and that is that we actually use English Sampa
from now on. No more archaic letter names, such as Pea and At. And no
Sampa X. I just read an email and couldn't follow it because it was in
Sampa X. Could we possibly agree to using this direct method before I do
more work on the font? I am very over-burdened as it is, so having to
try to keep Sampa X and the archaic letter names, as well as other
naming methods, is driving me crazy.

>
> For typing in email, I had in mind following QS-SAMPA, so "bird" would
> be /byrd/. If your font becomes the de-facto standard for ligatures,
> then of course /bPd/ would work as well, but that's an extension of
> QS-SAMPA that is very un-SAMPA-like. If someone sends me QS in
> plain-text, I wouldn't expect it to look as beautiful as a finished
> document with specified font size, etc. So if letters that could be in
> ligatures remain unconnected, that seems fine to me.

I think we may have to go with an un-SAMPA like solution for this one
case. To really use SAMPA, we should write /b3rd/. But there is no way
to get a font to handle /3r/. We need the number "3" as its own
character. If a font converts /3/ to some QS letter, we won't be able to
use "3," an obviously unworkable solution.

I feel that /3r/ is the one phoneme that is handled poorly at this
point. Since some of our time will be spent discussing this inadequacy,
and some of it will be spent discussing how to spell words with /3r/, I
think we should adopt a non-standard SAMPA letter. We can choose P if we
like. That way, if someone cuts and pasts /bPd/, into a word processer
and chooses ThothSampa, he will get a letter that makes sense. Also, in
the future, if we decide that /3r/ gets its own letter (something I hope
for), it becomes simpler to convert anything already written with P.

>
> Regarding the alternate letters 'Noon' and 'Up', I don't think it will
> be difficult to implement their use in software. All you have to do is
> substitute 'q' for 'n' and 'V' for 'y' in certain entries in your
> dictionary. This is what I had in mind:
> http://staff.washington.edu/freeman/qs/noon_up.pdf
> <http://staff.washington.edu/freeman/qs/noon_up.pdf>
>

I hadn't thought of making the changes in my dictionary. However, at
this point there is so much going on--new fonts, the lexical sets
discussion, the news, etc.--that I don't even want to think about senior
QS.

Paul
